content.webTitle: Billy Hart Quartet: One Is the Other review – 'Beautifully crafted references all over the jazz tradition'

fields.headline: Billy Hart Quartet: One Is the Other review – 'Beautifully crafted references all over the jazz tradition'
fields.bodyText: For anyone open to spontaneous musical conversation, regardless of genre, this beautifully crafted album is likely to appeal – but aficionados will probably get more from it, since veteran drum star and former Herbie Hancock sideman Hart and his superb quartet constantly hint at references from all over the jazz tradition. This is only the second ECM album from this long-running but occasional band, and it's even better than its captivating predecessor, 2012's All Our Reasons. Tenor saxophonist Mark Turner's opener, Lennie's Groove (dedicated to the 1950s cool-school piano guru Lennie Tristano that distantly suggests the Lee Konitz classic Subconscious-Lee) is a breathtakingly serpentine, bop-phrased sax/piano melody over a disorientatingly shifting rhythmic feel. Pianist Ethan Iverson's Maraschino is laterally bluesy, while Hart's Amethyst sounds contemporary-classical at first but Turner colours it with rich Charles Lloydian hues while drums and bass patter and snap. Yard sounds like 21st-century Charlie Parker and Thelonious Monk in tandem, and Some Enchanted Evening (the only standard) demonstrates Turner's capacity to turn melodic somersaults like an acrobat and land elegantly poised.
